key_risks: Compliance and ethical concerns, including FCPA violations and bribery allegations
Geopolitical tensions and regulatory scrutiny in multiple markets
Volatile financial performance and challenging mobile networks market
controversies: $206 million penalty for breaching a deferred prosecution agreement
Admission to a 'years-long campaign of corruption' including bribes to Islamic State terrorists in Iraq
environmental_issues: Commitment to achieving net-zero emissions by 2040
social_issues: Workforce reduction of 1,200 employees due to market challenges
governance_issues: Ongoing probation and oversight until June 2024 due to compliance failures
Significant legal and ethical challenges despite compliance program certification

sources.title: Ericsson Agrees To Pay Over USD $1 Billion To Settle FCPA Charges
sources.snippet: Ericsson's subsidiary, Ericsson Egypt Ltd., pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA. Ericsson also agreed to retain an independent compliance monitor for a term of three years. Penalties As part of its settlement, Ericsson will pay a $520 million criminal penalty to the DOJ

sources.title: Ericsson's sordid affair with DOJ raises questions on DPAs ...
sources.snippet: A critical examination of Ericsson's 2019 deferred prosecution agreement (DPA) and the Department of Justice's (DOJ) determination the Swedish telecommunications company breached the agreement raises questions regarding the overall lack of accountability in a yearslong, multijurisdictional corruption scheme.

sources.title: Ericsson's 'integrity journey' post-FCPA settlement top compliance ...
sources.snippet: In February 2022, Ericsson admitted it found evidence of "corruption-related misconduct in Iraq." A month later, the DOJ determined Ericsson breached the DPA a second time for "insufficient" disclosures. The monitorship was originally set to run until June 2023 before being extended an additional year.

sources.title: Ericsson agrees to $206m plea bargain with US in bribery case
sources.snippet: Ericsson CEO Börje Ekholm said in a statement that the guilty plea and fine "means that the matter of the breaches is now resolved" and that Ericsson is "a very different company today.". Ekholm said the new legal action is "a stark reminder of the historical misconduct" that led to the 2019 deal with the U.S. government.
